Line 385: Line 385:
On 14 February, the Palestinian Authority's [[Prime Minister]] [[Salam Fayyad]] and his Cabinet submitted its resignations to President Abbas<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/02/15/arab.region.unrest/index.html|work=CNN|title=Unrest in the Middle East and North Africa -- country by country|date=2011-02-18}}</ref> amid pan-Arab calls for reform. Abbas tasked him with forming a new government after consultations with other factions, institutions and civil society groups.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121484520923682.html|title=Palestinian cabinet resigns|publisher=Al Jazeera English|date=2011-02-14|accessdate=2011-02-19}}</ref> The reshuffle was long demanded by Fayyad and some in Abbas's Fatah faction.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121484520923682.html|title=Palestinian cabinet resigns|publisher=Al-Jazeera English|date=2011-02-14|accessdate=2011-02-14}}</ref>
On 14 February, the Palestinian Authority's [[Prime Minister]] [[Salam Fayyad]] and his Cabinet submitted its resignations to President Abbas<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/02/15/arab.region.unrest/index.html|work=CNN|title=Unrest in the Middle East and North Africa -- country by country|date=2011-02-18}}</ref> amid pan-Arab calls for reform. Abbas tasked him with forming a new government after consultations with other factions, institutions and civil society groups.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121484520923682.html|title=Palestinian cabinet resigns|publisher=Al Jazeera English|date=2011-02-14|accessdate=2011-02-19}}</ref> The reshuffle was long demanded by Fayyad and some in Abbas's Fatah faction.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121484520923682.html|title=Palestinian cabinet resigns|publisher=Al-Jazeera English|date=2011-02-14|accessdate=2011-02-14}}</ref>
  +   +
=== Qatar ===
  +
{{expand section}}
  +
As of March Qatar has thus far not experienced any protests. However, ''[[Agence France-Presse]]'' have reported that a ''Facebook'' group has been set up calling for the removal of Emir [[Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani]] and for Qataris to "hit the streets" on 16 March<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/167238.html|title=Qataris launch online freedom movement|publisher=Press TV|year=2011|accessdate=2011-03-01}}</ref> citing concerns over Qatar's slow pace of reform and ties with [[Israel]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newstimeafrica.com/archives/16371 |title=Government in Qatar slams Libyaâs violent crackdown on protesters |publisher=Newstime Africa |year=2011|accessdate=02-03-2011}}</ref>
